Package xxl.core.cursors

The package xxl.core.cursors provides a whole algebra of cursors that extends the functionality of the classes Iterator and Enumeration.

See:
          Description

Interface Summary
Cursor<E> A cursor extends the interface Iterator by adding functionality for opening and closing the cursor, i.e., reserving and releasing of system resources, taking a look at the next element that would be returned by call to next, updating elements of the underlying data structure and traversing it another time without constructing a new cursor.
MetaDataCursor<E,M> A metadata-cursor realizes a cursor additionally providing metadata.
 

Class Summary
AbstractCursor<E> An abstract cursor implements the methods of the interface Cursor and is useful in those cases when you produce elements and want to return them by a cursor.
AbstractMetaDataCursor<E,M> This class decorates an object implementing the interface Cursor such that it is able to provide metadata information.
Cursors This class contains various static methods for manipulating iterators.
DecoratorCursor<E> This class decorates an object implementing the interface Cursor such that all method calls on the decorator are passed to its decorated object.
ObservableIterator<E> This class provides a wrapper for iterators with the intention to observe them.
ResetableCursor<E> This class provides a wrapper that enhance a cursor (or iterator) that is not resetable by a reset functionality.
SecureDecoratorCursor<E> This class decorates an object implementing the interface Cursor such that all method calls on the decorator are passed to its decorated object.
Subquery<E> This class is a prototypical implementation for subqueries which may be used in exist, all, any predicates, etc.
 

Package xxl.core.cursors Description

The package xxl.core.cursors provides a whole algebra of cursors that extends the functionality of the classes Iterator and Enumeration. A cursor is an abstract concept for manipulating objects within a stream. The cursors provided in XXL are independent from the specific structure of the objects as well as from the kind of storage representation of the underlying stream. This property is closely related to the notion of physical independence which is one of the key concepts of database systems. XXL offers an algebra of cursors which is suitable for defining complex queries in a declarative fashion similar to SQL. In addition, our cursor algebra is also beneficial for a very compact implementation of low-level core functionality (e.g. index structures).

This package provides the interfaces and some fundamental classes of XXL's cursor algebra whereas its concrete operators are arranged into subpackages. If you want to get an overview of this package (and its subpackages) please take a closer look to section Cursors at our paper: XXL - A Library Approach to Supporting Efficient Implementations of Advanced Database Queries .
